results.title: What do you think about getting what you're after
results.creator_credit: Gundrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
This film invites discussion of whether, in business competition, one’s standards of fair play should be lowered. The question revolves around two young women who seek the same job. While one has already applied for the position and is reasonably sure of getting it, she lessens her chances by telling the other that applications are still being accepted. A third woman questions the first’s “softness” and the audience is asked to judge. No. 6 in the series.

results.title: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first of May is International Labour Day marking the struggle to achieve the eight hour working day. The Northern Territory is one of the few States still celebrating May 1st as a holiday. This program follows the preparations by community groups, trade unions and artistic directors, Neil Cameron and Jan McDonald, to revitalise the 1989 May Day celebrations in Darwin by creating a lively and colourful parade and festival where workers could have a good time and still prove unity is strength.
results.title_for_label: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]

results.title: What do you mean I've changed?: journeys through post-natal depression
results.brief_description: One in five women suffer from Post-natal depression (PND). In this short documentary, 3 women; Cindy Picton-Barnes, Susan King and Sandi Avery frankly discuss their experiences with PND - the physical and mental symptoms, self-doubt, fear and anxiety, and the treatment they found most effective. Also includes discussion with the womens’ partners and an expert from the Dona Maria Pre and Post-natal Support Network who outlines where women can go for help as well as what factors contribute to PND. Presented by Wendy Harmer, Patron of Dona Maria Post-Natal Support Network.

results.title: What do you know?: screen quiz No. 1
results.brief_description: A humorous film in a slightly slapstick style of a trivia quiz show. Asks such questions as: What is the weight of a dry Australian rules football? Where are a crab’s teeth found? Can a horse sleep standing up? etc. Relevent shots are shown relating to each question and choice answers are provided with a counting down clock. Includes footage of Melbourne, including Swanston and Collins Streets, and a game of Australian Rules football (Carlton vs Collingwood?). Interesting film from an historic point of view. Photography by David J. Bilcock. Written and narrated by Norman Ellis.

results.title: What do I tell my children?
results.creator_credit: Leslie Bellis Kussmann and Aquarius Productions
results.brief_description: This video is internationally recognised as the most outstanding available for families and professionals who are dealing with children and grief issues, Children and parents share their stories and feelings about the loss of a loved one, while leading professionals in the field - including Earl Grollman, Elsiabeth Kubler-Ross, Sandra Fox and Anne Kilman - offer advice about coping and grief. It looks at practical advice for dealing with different kinds of bereavement: sibling, parent and grandparent.

results.title: What do I know about Benny?
results.brief_description: Benny is achieving low grades in school and his discipline is poor. His mother discuses the situation with the school principal. The principal attempts to explain that Benny was achieving up to his ability level. The mother rejects this and blames his performance on bad teaching.

results.title: What do girls want from boys?
results.brief_description: An open ended film from the “Searching years” series in which a group of young people discuss the problems of dating at high school level and the needs of girls in a close relationship. Why do girls often prefer to date older boys? What does a girl mean when a ask to be “treated like a woman?”
